thread.title: Rupee seen weakening due to month-end dollar demand
thread.title_full: Rupee seen weakening due to month-end dollar demand | Business Standard News

author: BS Reporter
title: Rupee seen weakening due to month-end dollar demand
text:
The rupee is seen weakening this week due to month-end dollar buying by importers and government bond yields may start falling due to expectations of a rate cut in the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) fourth bi-monthly monetary policy review later this month.
On Friday the rupee appreciated to a one-month high and bond yields fell to an over three-month low after the US Fed decided to keep interest rates unchanged in its meeting. In percentage terms this kind of appreciation in the rupee was last seen in September 2013 after Raghuram Rajan had taken over as the governor of the central bank and had announced measured to cut volatility in the rupee.
"The US Fed decided to hold interest rates as a result of which stock market rallied on Friday. The rally in stock markets resulted in renewed interest by Foreign Institutional Investors (FIIs). The gains in rupee also helped government bonds as a result of which yields fell," said N S Venkatesh, executive director and head of treasury at IDBI Bank. According to Venkatesh this week the rupee may trade in the range of 65.50 to 66.25 per dollar with a weakening bias.
Friday the rupee had ended at 65.67 compared with previous close of 66.46 per dollar. The rupee had ended at 65.55 per dollar on August 20. In percentage terms the gain in rupee today was 1.19%. The rupee had last gained by 2.54% on September 19, 2013 to end at 61.78 per dollar.
The yield on the 10-year bond ended at 7.70% on Friday compared with previous close of 7.75%. The yield ended near a level last seen on June 1 at 7.64%. Expectations are building up in the bond market that the central bank may cut the repo rate or the rate at which banks borrow from RBI in the monetary policy review on September 29 due to which bonds may rally further this week.
